questions.text: A medical officer is conducting a forensic examination in a case involving a late-term abortion. To assist in determining the gestational age of the fetus at the time of the abortion, the medical officer is reviewing the mother's medical records for documented physical examination findings. External ballottement is a technique used to assess fetal development. After how many weeks of gestation can external ballottement typically be performed in a normal pregnancy?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 20 weeks

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • External ballottement , a technique where the fetus can be felt to rebound against the examiner's fingers during a pelvic examination, is typically possible after about 20 weeks of gestation . This is when the fetus is large enough to be palpated through the abdominal wall.
  • • External ballottement
  • • fetus can be felt to rebound against the examiner's fingers during a pelvic examination,
  • • possible after about 20 weeks of gestation
  • • fetus is large enough to be palpated
  • • Demonstration
  • • Demonstration
  • • Vaginal/internal ballottement : Two fingers are inserted into the anterior fornix and a sudden upward motion given . This causes the fetus to move up in the liquor amnii and after a moment, the fetus drops down on the fingers, like a ball bouncing back. External ballottement : A sudden motion is given to the abdominal wall covering the uterus, in a few seconds the rebound of the fetus can be felt.
  • • Vaginal/internal ballottement : Two fingers are inserted into the anterior fornix and a sudden upward motion given . This causes the fetus to move up in the liquor amnii and after a moment, the fetus drops down on the fingers, like a ball bouncing back.
  • • Vaginal/internal ballottement
  • • Two fingers are inserted into the anterior fornix
  • • upward motion given
  • • fetus to move up in the liquor amnii
  • • External ballottement : A sudden motion is given to the abdominal wall covering the uterus, in a few seconds the rebound of the fetus can be felt.
  • • External ballottement
  • • sudden motion is given to the abdominal wall covering the uterus,

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ballottement (toss up like a ball): This is positive during the 4th–5th month of pregnancy as the fetus is small in relation to the amount of amniotic fluid present . This is a useful clinical sign for assessing fetal development around the midpoint of the gestation period.
  • ➤ Ballottement (toss up like a ball):
  • ➤ positive during the 4th–5th month of pregnancy
  • ➤ fetus is small in relation to the amount of amniotic fluid present
  • ➤ Ref : Reddy 33/e. Pg 394
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ : Reddy 33/e. Pg 394

questions.text: In a pathology laboratory, a medical officer is analyzing tissue samples from a deceased pregnant woman who suddenly collapsed and died. The medical history and symptoms prior to death suggest a rare but serious complication. The medical officer decides to use Lendrum's stain in the histopathological examination of the lung tissue. For which type of embolism is Lendrum's stain specifically used?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Amniotic fluid embolism

  • • Option A . Air embolism : Not identifiable with Lendrum's stain .
  • • Option A
  • • Air embolism
  • • Not identifiable with Lendrum's stain
  • • Option B . Fat embolism : Detected through different staining techniques .
  • • Option B
  • • Fat embolism
  • • different staining techniques
  • • Option D. Pulmonary embolism : The nature of the embolus (e.g., thrombus, fat, air) dictates the staining technique, not the location.
  • • Option D.
  • • Pulmonary embolism
  • • nature of the embolus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Lendrum's stain is used in forensic pathology for the identification of amniotic fluid embolism , a critical diagnostic tool in cases of maternal death where this condition is suspected.

  • ➤ Immediate : Air embolism, fat embolism, amniotic fluid embolism , hemorrhage, vagal inhibition. Delayed (with 2 to 3 days): Septicemia, generalized peritonitis, tetanus , local infection & toxemia.

questions.text: In a lecture on child abuse, the professor discusses Caffey's Syndrome, a condition often associated with non-accidental injuries in children. The students are asked to identify which feature is not true regarding Caffey's Syndrome. Which of the following statements about Caffey's Syndrome is incorrect?

options.label: B
options.text: Undue delay in seeking medical advice

options.label: C
options.text: The history is consistent with the injuries

questions.correct_answer: C. The history is consistent with the injuries
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) The history is consistent with the injuries.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A . Injuries sustained are non-accidental : True , as Caffey's Syndrome is often linked to child abuse.
  • • Option A
  • • Injuries sustained are non-accidental
  • • True
  • • Option B . Undue delay in seeking medical advice: True , and this delay in seeking treatment is a common feature in child abuse cases.
  • • Option B
  • • Undue delay in seeking medical advice: True
  • • Option D . Injuries are of different duration: True , indicating repeated abuse over time, with injuries in various stages of healing.
  • • Option D
  • • Injuries are of different duration: True

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A battered child is one who has received repetitive physical injuries as a result of nonaccidental violence , produced by a parent or guardian . In addition to physical injury , there may be non-accidental deprivation of nutrition, care and affection . The key identifier is the inconsistency between the history provided and the injuries observed, which is a hallmark of non-accidental injury in child abuse cases.
  • ➤ battered child is one who has received repetitive physical injuries as a result of nonaccidental violence
  • ➤ parent or guardian
  • ➤ physical injury
  • ➤ non-accidental deprivation of nutrition, care and affection

  • ➤ Ref

questions.text: A group of medical students are discussing the medicolegal aspects associated with precipitate labor. One topic of particular interest is the risk of umbilical cord rupture. As part of their discussion, they focus on identifying the most common site of umbilical cord tear during such rapid deliveries. Umbilical cord in precipitate labor usually torn at?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Fetal end

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A . Placental end : Tearing at the placental end is less common because this end is typically more securely attached and less susceptible to the rapid forces experienced in precipitate labor.
  • • Option A
  • • Placental end
  • • less common because this end is typically more securely attached and less susceptible
  • • Option C . Mid part : The mid part of the umbilical cord is structurally stronger and less likely to tear under the stress of a rapid delivery compared to the fetal end.
  • • Option C
  • • Mid part
  • • mid part of the umbilical cord is structurally stronger
  • • less likely to tear
  • • Option D . Lower third part : This is not a common site of rupture during precipitate labor. The stress on the umbilical cord during rapid delivery is more likely to affect the fetal end, where the cord is attached to the fetus and thus more vulnerable.
  • • Option D
  • • Lower third part
  • • not a common site of rupture

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In precipitate labor all three stages of labor merge into one (mostly in multipara). Cord is torn most commonly at the fetal end than the placental end, but is not torn in its middle part or the placenta is expelled with the child.
  • ➤ precipitate labor all three stages of labor merge into one
  • ➤ Cord is torn most commonly at the fetal end
  • ➤ Differentiation between Head injury due to precipitate labor and blunt force –
  • ➤ Differentiation between Head injury due to precipitate labor and blunt force –
  • ➤ Ref : Reddy 33/e. Pg 443
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ : Reddy 33/e. Pg 443

questions.text: During a legal conference on reproductive rights, a forensic expert is discussing the definition of abortion in the context of gestational age. questions.text: A forensic expert is conducting a workshop on various tests used to determine live birth in cases of infant death. These tests are essential to distinguish between infants who were born alive and those who were stillborn. Which of the following tests is not used to detect live birth?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Winslow test

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A . Fodere's test is used to demonstrate lung floatation , indicative of breathing and thus live birth . The lungs are ligated across their hila and separated . The average weight of both lungs before respiration varies from 30 to 40 g., and after respiration from 60 to 66 g. The increase in weight is due to the increased flow of blood.
  • • Option A
  • • Fodere's test
  • • demonstrate lung floatation
  • • breathing and thus live birth
  • • ligated across their hila and separated
  • • Option B . Ploucquet's test is another lung floatation test used to determine if an infant had breathed . The ratio of the weight of the lungs and the whole body is reduced to half (1/35 of body weight) as compared to the said ratio before respiration (1/70 of body weight).
  • • Option B
  • • Ploucquet's test
  • • lung floatation test
  • • if an infant had breathed
  • • Option C . Wredin's test - Before birth , the middle ear contains gelatinous embryonic connective tissue but no air . With respiration, the sphincter at the pharyngeal end of eustachian tube relaxes and air replaces the gelatinous substances in few hours to five weeks.
  • • Option C
  • • Wredin's test
  • • Before birth
  • • middle ear contains gelatinous embryonic connective tissue but no air

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

  • ➤ forensic tests used to detect live birth

  • ➤ Winslow test = test to determine stoppage of respiration

  • ➤ weight of lungs before respiration -30 to 40 g after respiration-60 to 66 g
  • ➤ Plocquet's test = ratio of weight of lungs to weight of body ; before respiration = 1:70 and after respiration = 1:35
  • ➤ Plocquet's test
  • ➤ weight of lungs to weight of body
  • ➤ Wredin's test = before respiration gelatinous tissue in middle ear & after respiration , air in middle ear

questions.text: A forensic medicine student is studying the Spalding sign, a radiological indication of intrauterine fetal death. The student is asked about the presentation of the fetus where the Spalding sign is likely to develop earlier. Which fetal presentation is associated with an earlier development of the Spalding sign?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Vertex presentation

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Spalding sign - Loss of alignment and overriding of the bones of the cranial vault occur due to shrinkage of the cerebrum (brain) after death of the foetus . The sign will develop earlier with a vertex presentation than with a breech. It may be detected within 2 days of death of the foetus.
  • • Spalding sign

  • • shrinkage of the cerebrum
  • • death of the foetus
  • • within 2 days of death
  • • It is seen on X ray or ultrasound.
  • • seen on X ray
  • • It is a sign of Maceration
  • • Maceration
  • • Image shows overlapping of skull bones on ultrasound (Spalding sign)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of intrauterine fetal death (X ray/USG), the Spalding sign, characterized by overlapping skull bones , develops earlier in fetuses with a vertex presentation . This is because the pressure changes in the skull are more pronounced in this position after death.
  • ➤ intrauterine fetal death
  • ➤ Spalding sign, characterized by overlapping skull bones
  • ➤ vertex presentation
  • ➤ This is the sign of maceration.
  • ➤ Ref : Reddy 33/e. Pg 437-438

  • ➤ : Reddy 33/e. Pg 437-438

(2) Maceration is a process of aseptic autolysis , occurs when the dead child remains in the uterus for about three or four days surrounded with liquor amnii but the exclusion of air. If air enters the liquor amnii after death of the foetus, putrefaction occurs instead of maceration.

  • • Option C

  • • unexplained death of a baby
  • • Option D . Maceration is a process that occurs if the fetus is retained in utero after its death , not applicable for deaths during delivery.

  • • Maceration
  • • fetus is retained in utero after its death

questions.text: A forensic resident is determining the necessity of performing a hydrostatic test in various scenarios involving fetal deaths. The hydrostatic test is used to assess whether the fetus had ever breathed. In which of the following situations is the hydrostatic test still required?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Stillborn fetus

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A . Maceration indicates prolonged intrauterine death , negating the need for a hydrostatic test.
  • • Option A
  • • Maceration indicates prolonged intrauterine death
  • • Option B . The presence of milk in the stomach suggests postnatal ingestion , making the hydrostatic test irrelevant.
  • • Option B
  • • presence of milk in the stomach suggests postnatal ingestion
  • • Option D . Anencephalic fetuses are typically incapable of independent respiration , making the test unnecessary.
  • • Option D
  • • Anencephalic fetuses are typically incapable of independent respiration

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Learning the indications for performing the hydrostatic test in fetal autopsies to determine if the fetus had breathed . Hydrostatic test is not necessary if : Fetus shows congenital anomaly , like anencephaly ; Fetus is macerated or mummified ; Umbilical cord has separated and a scar has formed; Stomach contains milk ; Bruises on lungs indicating efforts to artificially respirate the child; Fetus is born before 180 days of gestation.

questions.text: In a medicolegal autopsy of a newborn, a forensic expert is tasked with determining whether the infant had survived after birth and for how long. One critical aspect of the assessment is examining the status of the ductus arteriosus, as its closure timeline can provide valuable insights in cases of suspected neonatal demise under suspicious circumstances. How many days after live birth does the ductus arteriosus typically close?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 10 days

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • After birth , significant physiological changes occur in a child's circulatory system as it adapts from fetal to neonatal circulation. One of the critical changes is the closure of the ductus arteriosus, a vital component of fetal circulation that allows blood to bypass the lungs . This closure typically occurs functionally within 10 days post-birth. The process begins with the contraction of the umbilical arteries, which usually starts within ten hours and completes by the third day.
  • • After birth
  • • physiological changes occur in a child's circulatory system as it adapts from fetal to neonatal circulation.
  • • closure of the ductus arteriosus,
  • • fetal circulation that allows blood to bypass the lungs
  • • within 10 days post-birth.
  • • Additionaly, the timings of the closure of umbilical vein, ductus venosus, foramen ovale, is essential for forensic experts to understand the newborn's adaptation to extrauterine life and can provide valuable insights in cases of neonatal demise under suspicious circumstances.

questions.text: During a forensic investigation involving the death of a newborn, a forensic Expert is examining the body to determine the age of the infant at the time of death. One of the key indicators in such cases is the stage of healing of the umbilical stump, known as cicatrisation. How many days after birth is cicatrisation of the umbilicus typically seen?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 12 days

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Changes in Umblical Cord - The blood clots in the cut end 2 hours after birth , and the vessels begin to be closed in about 24 hours . The cord attached to the child shrinks and dries in 12 to 24 hours , but this appearance is also seen in the body of a stillborn infant , and an inflammatory ring forms at its base in 36 to 48 hours . It mummifies on second or third day. Mummification of the cord also occurs after death if exposed to air but does not occur if the child is submerged in water immediately after birth. The cord falls off on the fifth or sixth day and leaves an ulcer, which heals and forms a scar (Cicatrisation) in 10 to 12 days .
  • • Changes in Umblical Cord -

  • • 10 to 12 days

questions.text: During a PG seminar, the topic of discussion is the common misconceptions and facts about cot death, also known as Sudden Infant Death Syndrome (SIDS). The participants are tasked with identifying false statements regarding SIDS. Which of the following statements about cot death is false?

options.label: A
options.text: Increased incidence if mother is alcoholic

options.label: B
options.text: Most common finding is petechial hemorrhage on visceral surface of heart, lungs, thymus

options.label: C
options.text: It is a cause of negative autopsy

questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Slightly female predominance

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A . Increased incidence if mother is alcoholic : This statement is true . There is evidence suggesting that maternal alcohol consumption can increase the risk of SIDS. Alcohol use during pregnancy can affect fetal development and may lead to conditions that predispose an infant to SIDS.
  • • Option A
  • • Increased incidence if mother is alcoholic
  • • statement is true
  • • Option B . Most common finding is petechial hemorrhage on visceral surface of heart, lungs, thymus: This is also a true statement . In cases of SIDS, one of the most common autopsy findings is petechial hemorrhages, particularly on the visceral surfaces of the heart, lungs, and thymus. These tiny, pinpoint hemorrhages can be indicative of SIDS but are not exclusive to it.
  • • Option B
  • • Most common finding is petechial hemorrhage on visceral surface of heart, lungs, thymus:
  • • true statement
  • • Option C . It is a cause of negative autopsy : This statement is accurate . SIDS is often diagnosed when an autopsy does not reveal an adequate explanation for an infant's death. The term 'negative autopsy' is used because, despite thorough examination, no definitive cause of death can be identified. SIDS is essentially a diagnosis of exclusion, made after ruling out other potential causes of death.
  • • Option C
  • • It is a cause of negative autopsy
  • • accurate

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Correcting misconceptions about Sudden Infant Death Syndrome , particularly regarding its gender distribution. Male infants have a proportionately higher death rate (M:F ratio 3:2).

  • ➤ Male infants have a proportionately higher death rate

questions.text: In a rural district hospital, a medical officer was called to investigate a distressing case involving a newborn found abandoned near a local pond. The circumstances surrounding the newborn's discovery raised concerns about possible infanticide. To assist in the investigation, the medical officer decided to perform a series of tests as part of the autopsy to determine whether the newborn had been born alive and breathed before death. In which test weight of lungs is compared with body weight?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Ploucquet's Test

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Static test or Fodere's test: The test based on lung weight useful in the diagnosis of live birth is static test . The average weight of both lungs before respiration is 35 gm and after respiration is 70 gm. There is no comparison with the body weight.
  • • Option A. Static test or Fodere's test:
  • • test based on lung weight useful in the diagnosis of live birth is static test
  • • Option C. Raygat’s test (Hydrostatic test, Breslau’s 1st life test): Raygat’s test is based on specific gravity of lung . The specific gravity of a non-respired lung is 1040-1050 and of a respired lung is 940-950, so, after respiration lung floats on water (specific gravity of water is 1000). There is no comparison of lung weight to body weight.
  • • Option C. Raygat’s test (Hydrostatic test, Breslau’s 1st life test):
  • • Raygat’s test is based on specific gravity of lung
  • • Option D. Wredin's test: This test is based on the fact that before birth middle ear contains gelatinous embryonic tissue , which is replaced by air after respiration. So, the presence of air in middle ears denotes live birth. There is no role of weight of lungs.
  • • Option D. Wredin's test: This test is based on the fact that before birth middle ear contains gelatinous embryonic tissue

questions.text: In a challenging case of suspected neonatal demise under ambiguous circumstances, a forensic expert was tasked with conducting an autopsy to ascertain the viability and respiratory status of the neonate at birth.   • • introduces air into the lungs, which would likely cause the lungs to float
  • • Option C. Emphysema : Neonatal emphysema, characterized by overinflation of the lungs, would more likely cause the lungs to float, which does not correspond to a false-negative result.
  • • Option C.
  • • Emphysema
  • • characterized by overinflation of the lungs,
  • • Option D . Putrefaction : Putrefaction involves the production of gases within the body's tissues, including the lungs, after death . This process could lead to a false-positive result in the hydrostatic test, as the gas might cause the lungs to float, falsely indicating that the neonate had initiated respiration.
  • • Option D

  • • the production of gases within the body's tissues, including the lungs, after death
